#InternImpacts üí• Meet Jade Lopez-Case, a rising star in oceanography and one of our #summerinterns at NRL! With a physics degree from Rollins College and a PhD in Ocean Engineering from the University of Rhode Island, she is making waves in underwater acoustics. Jade's passion for the ocean ignited during childhood beach days in Florida. This fascination fueled a #STEM-focused path, leading to a career dedicated to understanding and harnessing the ocean's potential. Her research delves into the complexities of acoustic propagation, exploring how factors like temperature, sea state, and seabed composition impact sonar performance. By unraveling these underwater mysteries, Jade is directly contributing to the Navy's mission. Her work in geoacoustic inversion is crucial for creating accurate models of the ocean floor, improving sonar detection and range accuracy. Ultimately, this leads to better-informed tactical decisions for our naval forces. As a #NREIP intern, Jade has embraced every opportunity to learn and grow. From collaborating with seasoned researchers to attending informative talks, she has immersed herself in the NRL community. "The best part about working at NRL is the sense of fulfillment that comes from being present in a collaborative environment," said Jade. "Each branch is filled with individuals that have expertise in different research areas, yet they often come together to exchange ideas and help each other out." We're excited to see where Jade will go next! Her dedication and talent are an inspiration to future oceanographers and scientists. üåü üåä US Navy United States Department of Defense United States Marine Corps Rollins College University of Rhode Island #NRLintern #oceanography #acoustics #STEM #research #futureleaders #navalSTEM #education #leader #DODintern #science #futuretech #NRL #NRLresearch #collaboration #revolutionize #STEMIntern #DODEducation

Making Waves for Marines: NRL's LittoralLens Showcased at Expo! üåä The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory (NRL) and Office of Naval Research-Global (ONR-Global) TechSolutions unveiled the game-changing LittoralLens system at the Modern Day Marine Expo! What is it? This portable, single-person system uses advanced computer vision to measure wave statistics and water velocities in real-time. Think of it as a surf zone oracle for Marines! Benefits for Marines? üåä Safer OMFTS: LittoralLens provides critical data for amphibious landings, reducing risks and increasing operational efficiency. üåä Real-time Awareness: Get instant insights into the surf zone, allowing for faster, more informed decisions. üåä Easy to Use: Point-and-shoot simplicity thanks to cutting-edge NRL-patented technology! What's Next? This month, Marines will put LittoralLens to the test at a final demonstration. Stay tuned for updates on this groundbreaking technology! P.S. Want to learn more about TechSolutions? #TechTuesday Joystick Remote Control Circuit Patent In 1926, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory's C.B. Mirick patented his system for remote radio control of pilotless aircraft (or of "any circuits or objects which are to be controlled at a distance") using a " 'joy stick' identical with the 'joy stick' provided in aircraft." U.S. Patent no. 1,597,416, "Electrical Distant-Control System," Aug. 24, 1926. "my invention relates broadly to distant control systems, and more particularly to a control circuit for a radio transmitter, and a selectively responsive circuit for a radio apparatus whereby particular controls may be caused to function individually or simultaneously." Tiny particles in the air, often invisible to the naked eye, are playing a surprisingly big role in our weather! üåßÔ∏è The U.S. Naval Research Lab (NRL) and National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)'s Cloud, Aerosol and Monsoon Processes Philippines Experiment (CAMP2Ex) mission focuses on studying the role of aerosol particles, and the relationships between the particles with monsoon meteorology in the Philippines. By understanding how aerosols impact our climate system, we can better predict extreme weather events and develop strategies to protect our planet.
